Description: Gold bracelet in the form of a serpent: comprising a solid gold rod that has been twisted into a coil that forms the body of the snake. Only the scales of the forepart and tail of the snake have been indicated by chasing, and even then, only on the top surface. The snake's mouth is slightly opened, showing the lightly indicated teeth.
Curator's comments: Pair with 1917.0601.2780. Similar spiral bracelets have been found in Egypt and at Pompeii and Boscoreale in Italy. Bibliography: F.H. Marshall, 'Catalogue of Jewellery, Greek, Etrusean and Roman in the Department of Antiquities, British Museum' (London, 1911), nos 2780-1; R. Blurton (ed.), 'The Enduring Image: Treasures from the British Museum' (London, 1997), cat.no.98; C. Johns, discussion of snake bracelets in S. Walker (ed.), 'Ancient Faces' (exh. cat., The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York) (New York 2000), pp. 151-2; S. Walker & P. Higgs [eds.], 'Cleopatra of Egypt' (London, 2001), p. 318 [334].
Bibliographic references: Jewellery / Catalogue of the Jewellery, Greek, Etruscan, and Roman, in the Departments of Antiquities, British Museum. (2781) (?)
Walker & Higgs 2001 / Cleopatra of Egypt: from History to Myth (334)
